oaidtb.filters
Class AbstractNominalToOCFilter

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--weka.filters.Filter
        |
        +--oaidtb.filters.AbstractNominalToOCFilter
All Implemented Interfaces:
weka.core.OptionHandler, java.io.Serializable
Direct Known Subclasses:
AbstractNominalToRandomOCFilter
public abstract class AbstractNominalToOCFilter
extends weka.filters.Filter
implements weka.core.OptionHandler

Abstract class defining the structure and common code to our nominal to output codes classes. For an approach to output codes in machine learning theory, see: Dietterich, T. G., Bakiri, G. (1995) Solving Multiclass Learning Problems via Error-Correcting Output Codes. Journal of Artificial Intelligence Research 2: 263-286. 

 How is stored the code?. We use a fixed array of Java's ArrayBits, where:
   - Each BitSet correspond to one attribute's value (normally the class). Of course, it must be nominal.
   - A bit in the nth position of a BitSet informs about in with subset is a value in the nth partition.
   - We call "code word" to each BitSet.

 Look at this matrix:

 BitSet (Class Value) -->               0 1 2 3 4 ... numDistinctValues()
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
 Partition 0                      |     1 0 1 0 1 ...
 Partition 1                      |     0 0 1 0 1 ...
 Partition 2                      |     1 1 0 0 0 ...
 Partition ...                    |     .............

   ** Each row is a partition.
   ** Each column is a code word.

 Of course, this hold method can be changed by subclasses.

 Why program them with the appearance of a weka's filter, when obviously it's unnecessary complex?
   - Learn about how weka filters work.
   - It could be useful for other purposes than simply use them in AdaBoostOC;
     output codes are a standalone topic in machine learning theory.

Version:
$Revision: 1.0 $
Author:
Santiago David Villalba Bartolomé

m_OutputCode

protected java.util.BitSet[] m_OutputCode
Generated code.

m_NumGeneratedPartitions

protected int m_NumGeneratedPartitions
Number of generated partitions. It must be compact/not fragmented (it doesn't exist not generated partitions).

m_ProcessedAttribute

protected int m_ProcessedAttribute
Index of processed attribute in the input dataset (it will be transformed into a binary one in the output dataset).

Flag to know if m_ProcessedAttribute has been set by the user explicitly.

newPartition

public void newPartition(weka.core.Instances instances)
                  throws java.lang.Exception
Generate a new partition incrementing the number of partitions generated, and so incrementing by 1 the length of all code words. It's equivalent to newPartition(instances, m_NumGeneratedPartitions), but it must be implemented to be faster.
Parameters:
instances - Perhaps a subclasss will use some information of them.
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - If an error occurs.

getCode

public int getCode(int numPartition,
                   int attValue)
Get to which subset (0 or 1) belongs the attribute value "attValue" at partition "numPartition". It doesn't make any parameter error control, so be careful.
Parameters:
numPartition - The partition to look at.
attValue - The value we ask to which set belongs.
Returns:
The set (0 or 1).

input

public boolean input(weka.core.Instance instance)

Specify attribute index to be processed. (default last attribute or class attribute if it's set)

setProcessedAttribute

public void setProcessedAttribute(int processedAttribute)
Sets the (nominal, numDifferentValues > 2) attribute which will be processed. A priori, it doesn't know anything about the dataset, so no error control is done. If it's called with a value less than 0, the filter will choose the class attribute or the last attribute if class isn't defined when a call to setInputFormat() is done.
Parameters:
processedAttribute - The attribute (index) which will be processed.

getProcessedAttribute

public int getProcessedAttribute()
Get the processed attribute index.
Returns:
The processed attribute index.
